greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the least index such that the least primitive root of the a(n)-th prime is n, or zero if no such prime exists.
comment: The corresponding primes are in A023048.
For n < 150, only a(108) is presently unknown. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jan 03 2006
link: Tomás Oliveira e Silva, Least prime primitive root of prime numbers
Index entries for primes by primitive root
formula: a(n) = 0 iff n is a perfect power (A001597) > 1. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jan 03 2006
example: a(6) = 13 because Prime[13] = 41 is the least prime with least primitive root = 6
mathematica: big = Table[ p = Prime[ n ]; PrimitiveRoot[ p ], {n, 1, 1000000} ]; Flatten[ Table[ Position[ big, n, 1, 1 ]/.{}-> 0, {n, 79} ] ] (* First load package NumberTheory`NumberTheoryFunctions` *)

(* first load package *) << NumberTheory`NumberTheoryFunctions` (* then do *) t = Table[0, {100}]; Do[a = PrimitiveRoot@Prime@n; If[a < 101 && t[[a]] == 0, t[[a]] = n], {n, 10^6}]; t (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Dec 15 2005 *)
results.author: _Wouter Meeussen_, Jan 06 2002
ext: Further terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jan 03 2006
